Well, one could, but why would one want to? One could, for example, take an overdose of sedatives or narcotics. Just the right dose would cause a reversible coma. A little too much would be fatal. Besides, one wouldn’t be aware of anything during the coma. Things like deep meditation, trance, and self-hypnosis are less dangerous and probably more enjoyable states that one might be able to self-induce. These might bear some resemblance to coma to outside observers, but they aren’t the same thing.

A coma is defined in medical terms as a period of unconsciousness where an individual is unrousable and cannot be woken. A common way of measuring level of consciousness is by using the Glasgow Coma Scale. (Glasgow Coma Scale)A level of 8/15 would indicate a fairly deep level unconsciousness. It is entirely possible to render oneself unconscious. This can be due to drugs, commonly opiates, alcohol misuse, inhalation of various substances. The danger is that the condition may not be reversible.

I presume you are talking about psychological strategies, and not doing things like taking an overdose or beating one’s head in a with a hammer. If we are only talking about psychological methods, I would say “No.” One can induce a deep hypnotic state, but some form of consciousness is preserved. The term “coma” is a neurological term referring to a persistent loss of consciousness, which means a decoupling of higher and lower brain functions. It is an indication of very serious dysfunction within the brain.

response.answer_text: Yes but don't try it, it can often be deadly.  Some narcotics can cause a coma, but because the dosage is uncertain, it can also cause death.  There are other ways, but they all hold the same risk.  Overdo whatever you are trying and you can die.  For example no one really knows exactly how much blunt force trauma your head could stand so you become comatose, rather than dead.

Possibly. You could with a fall where you severely hit your head or an overdose of medicines, mostly with sedatives or narcotics. The big question is why would you want to? You have no control over how your body would react and you might end up dying or become severely impaired both physically and mentally. If you feel strongly about trying it, you should first talk with someone you trust, your parents, a psychiatrist or a minister, maybe all three.

DON’T GO THERE! This is not something one would want to do. Comas are inevitably associated with some sort of severe illness—and even brain damage. Individual not managing their blood sugar in diabetes can lapse into a coma. Even if they “recover” they may have brain damage ranging from mild to severe. Coma is best read about and observed—not experienced!
